Instrument_Host_PDS3.instrument_host_desc:
Instrument Host Overview ========================
The Magdalena Ridge Observatory (MRO) is primarily intended for astronomical research and is composed of two facilities, a single 2.4-Meter telescope and an array of optical/infrared telescopes called an Interferometer. It is located on South Baldy Ridge in the Magdalena mountains, some 30 miles west of the New Mexico Tech (NMT) campus. At an elevation of 10,600 ft. above sea level, it is the fourth highest observatory in the world.
The MRO 2.4-meter Telescope is primarily utilized to observe, track, and characterize solar system astronomical targets, Earth satellites, space vehicles, and terrestrial military targets.
The 2.4-meter telescope has three basic objectives:
* Classical astronomical research * DoD mission support (satellite remote sensing, space surveillance, and missile tracking) * Supporting and enhancing education and public outreach
The telescope's rapid tracking (slew rates are 10 degrees/sec) capability facilitates characterization studies of resident space objects in low-Earth orbits. Further, the facility can be used to respond to targets of opportunity that occur in asteroid studies (e.g., Near Earth Objects) and in astrophysics, such as gamma ray bursts and other transient phenomena. Instrumentation includes a 4k x 4k CCD imager (with a standard UBVRI Bessel broadband filter set) and a high frame rate Andor Technology CCD camera, which is on loan from Williams College. The 4K imager's field of view extends to 11 arc minutes square, and this system has a 5-sigma detection limit of V~24.
First light for the 2.4 meter telescope occurred on October 31, 2006, and the observatory transitioned to an operational phase in September 2008.
The telescope was manufactured by EOS Technologies, Inc. (Tucson, Arizona); the architectural and engineering firm that designed the support structures for the project was Dekker/Perich/Sabatini (Albuquerque, NM); the telescope foundation was done by AUI, Inc. (Albuquerque, NM); the pier, telescope enclosure, and control building was constructed by Rio Conchos Corporation (Albuquerque, New Mexico); and the 40-foot, fast-tracking dome for the telescope enclosure was manufactured by Observa-Dome (Jackson, MS).
